normalised: So, I’ve been working in corporate India for a good seven years now. And let me tell you, scheduling meetings across time zones, especially when involving international colleagues, is a special kind of challenge. It’s not just about converting times; it’s about understanding the nuances of “Indian Stretchable Time” and the occasional insistence on holding calls at absolutely bonkers hours.

normalised: My first brush with this was way back in two thousand and sixteen, when I was still a wide-eyed newbie. We had a crucial project kickoff with the team in New York. The meeting was scheduled for nine thirty P-M I-S-T. I remember setting multiple alarms because, you know, sleep. Of course, then the meeting got "preponed" (Indian English for moved earlier) to eight P-M I-S-T at the last minute – thanks to some "urgent" matter on the U-S side that couldn’t possibly wait. I survived, fueled by copious amounts of chai.

normalised: There was also the infamous "Diwali Incident" of two thousand twenty one.
